content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy B{B} in this game for several reasons:

1. The payoff for both players is higher when both choices are B, earning each 12$ per round instead of 45$ per round for picking R against their choice. However, the gap between the two payoffs (12$ vs 45$) is larger than the gap between the worst-case scenario and the average case when choosing B (0$ vs 12$).

2. The game has 75 rounds. In this setup, it is more likely that my opponent will choose R initially because of the higher payoff in the first few rounds. However, as they realize that I earn more money over time by consistently picking B, they may start to switch their strategy and pick B as well. If we both adapt our strategies to each other's choices, it is likely that we will end up with a repeated pattern of B-B selections.

3. When my opponent chooses R, I earn 42$ per round compared to the 0$ I would earn if I pick R against their choice. Since there are more rounds in which they choose R than rounds in which I switch to R (given that there is no information about their strategy beforehand), it is advantageous for me to stick with B for the majority of the game and adapt my choices based on their actions.

4. Lastly, since there's no way for me to know whether my opponent will stick with R or switch to B, I should pick a strategy that provides me with the highest average payoff in the long run. In this case, strategy B{B} offers a higher average payoff than strategy R{R}.

So, based on these rationales, I would choose strategy B{B} for this game.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.

Since my opponent and I both picked B in the previous round, our payoff was 12$ each. In the next round, I will again pick strategy B{B} to continue maximizing my long-term payoff. This is because I assume that my opponent has also noticed the higher average payoff when choosing B consistently and will likely stick with their choice of B for future rounds as well. By doing so, we maintain the pattern of alternating between R and B, which results in a steady 12$ payoff per round for both players.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.

I will continue choosing strategy B{B} for the next round and every subsequent round in this experiment. The reasoning behind my choice remains unchanged, as sticking with B maximizes the long-term average payoff by consistently earning a steady 12$ per round compared to the potential gains from switching to R in specific rounds. Additionally, I assume that my opponent will also continue choosing strategy B for future rounds due to the observed pattern of mutual consistency and the higher long-term average payoff associated with this strategy.
